Legge or the other, some of the other people we've interviewed and all of us in the room are like,
no, I yeah, I've struggled, but I always knew I could ask. I mean, I could,
there were people I could go to, maybe not everyone, but there were people I could go to
and discuss these things with. So anyway, that's just one I'm striking me that we're defining
friendship now in terms of not of people who draw us near to Christ or who draws near to the,
to the truth, which might be a more secular way of saying it. Friends are friends, friends are
people who draw you near to the truth. It's now friends are people who affirm whatever I feel in
the moment. And that's not a lighthouse. That's quicksand. It's almost the opposite. So anyway,
that struck me as an anchor that believers need to be considering in their lives.
Yep. Yeah, that's good. What were the other, what were the other ones?
So from a, from a belief perspective, one of them is kind of funny, which is,
which Mark talked about, which was the, you know, Mark, one of the things that Mark said in the
podcast with him was, you know, right answers are the best answer tends to win is, is, was one of his,
one of his posits as a philosopher, he's like the best. I don't remember exactly the way he said it,
but it was something like that. Yeah. Like the best thought wins, the best thought wins. And so
even though there've been lots of other thoughts thrown at the best thoughts for thousands of
years, somehow still 90 plus percent of humans are theists. And, you know, one out of every three is
Christian and or claims to be like, it turns out that, you know, maybe the God's word is the anvil
around which the hammers lay broken. And, and it always feels scary to us when people come up with
new hammers and we're like, Oh no, now there's a, like, and then, then you read about, you know,
the church in Africa, you know, the church in America is fading. And then you read about the
church in Africa and the church in Asia that are exploding. Yeah. Like, okay. We've, we had our
shot and maybe, maybe we've kind of blown it for a while and we'll have to be brought back at some
point. Who knows? But anyway, that was, that's comforting to me in one sense, because one of the
things that struck us, struck me in those conversations with that I've had with Mark over
the years is that it's not like the other options have are somehow better. And so that's one of
the questions is, do I improve on my likelihood of being right by jumping ship? But again,
my mindset is not just jumping ship. I would have to jump to another ship. And I think that's
something that a lot of people don't do. They think they can just jump out of any ship and they'll be
fine. And I don't, I don't trust that. That's a deconstruction without reconstruction. But
Christian, I have to go back and listen to Mark's, Mark's interview with us because he talked about
the, what was it? The evolutionary argument against naturalism. And he explained it and it was
that it's a, I think it's a Paddinger. I don't remember who it was. But anyway, the philosopher
who's just created this pretty airtight argument against naturalism, if you believe in secular
evolution, that secular evolution disproves naturalism. And so it's kind of a, it's anyway,
fighting fire with fire a little bit there. But the, but man, so my big ones are,
if there is a God, would the world look like this? And if there was a God, what would that God be
like? And I always go back to the fact that you would need, if there's going to be a God,
and I do think there is, I think all the arguments show that really well. And so I've kind of walked
past the fear of there not being one or the concern of there not being a God at all for a lot of
reasons. But if there was one, what would He need to be like? And I just feel like of all the religions
of the world, the only one that gives a rational picture of what a creative God would be like
is kind of the Judeo-Christian model. All the other gods don't make any sense in my mind,
having read their holy books. And so I'm left with this, there needs to be a God who is benevolent,
and yet who offers freedom. Otherwise, why bother to create? I can't wrap my brain around
why any being would bother to create unless it was for a relationship. And in order for a
relationship, you would need to offer love and freedom. And so that's why I have children not
just build robots. And that's why I have friends not just have my computer program to say nice
things to me. I have friends outside of chat GPT. And so anyway, that's only the Judeo-Christian
God fulfills those two things, is initially benevolent and loving and also offers freedom.
So that to me is an anchor I go back to. It's like, okay, yeah, that's still the truth. And then
I've realized I would just need a better explanation for Christianity in particular,
I would need a better explanation for everything that surrounds the resurrection.
One, not how does a guy get dead? Romans killed people all the time, but how does that same guy
get to be alive? And that includes things like why did his disciples behave the way they did?
You've got to offer me an explanation for why a group of men really bought into this. And they
all did. And they all stuck with it. All of the original eyewitnesses stuck with it. And most of
them were tortured to death for believing it. And the failure rate was zero. And that's not just not
how people work. I know people and that's not how people work. You just, you can't do it. It's hard
enough to stick with the truth under pressure, much less to stick with something you know is a
lie under pressure. It's just not plausible. And so there's not been anything offered up that I
think offers even a close to rational explanation outside of the idea that there was a resurrection
and they experienced it. So that's so good. And then so kind of shifting then, unless Chris shared,
is there anything you wanted to say in response to that? No, no, that's great. Great. I agree.
So we were talking before we started recording about Chris shared, you're saying that you guys
are seeing a kind of a shift in apologetics. We're seeing kind of this shift from traditional
identity to modern identity to gospel, you know, or not necessarily a shift, but just
some stark differences there. To me, this is like, okay, that there is a need for anchors,
because it doesn't take long for culture to shift really drastically. And if you don't have an
anchor or a set of anchors or whatever, it's easy to kind of get caught in the rush of everything.
And so in my mind, sorry, my computer started doing weird things.
Let's start that over again. Well, so in my mind, how are we as church leaders, as men, as people who
are, you know, within our circle of influence, how are we raising up a generation that is anchored?
Wow. You know, and so what, what are we kind of helping train our kids or our neighbors or those
we are discipling or discipling with, with, excuse me, to have those anchors as well? What would you
say to people who are listening to this? And they're like, Hey, I'm not necessarily right now
struggling with my identity in Christ, but I fear for my children who are coming up in a very
different culture than I did. And I want to help lay a good foundation, kind of set anchors for them.
What would you, what would you encourage them to maybe start doing or I don't know, what is,
what kind of, does that get anything going on in your brain?
I mean, I've been doing a podcast. Yeah, there you go. That's true. Sorry. What are you gonna say,
Chris? No, well, it's just, I think it's going back to the basics because I know I quoted this
in one of our podcasts before, but GK Chesterton said once that we, we used to be
more confident about the truth and skeptical about ourselves.
And now things have shifted and he was saying this a long time ago, where we're skeptical of
the truth and more confident in ourselves. And I think it's what you've said, Chris, already,
before, about deconstructing our faith in man and ourselves that we're just so inundated with
the idea that you can figure it out and you decide in your own highest authority. And that is so
appealing to us as humans who naturally want self-legislation, self-gratification. And so
that's really appealing, but it just leaves it in a really scary thing. Like you're, you don't have
anything solid. Years ago when Greg Kochel and Francis Beckwith wrote their book on relativism,
they call it feet planted firmly in midair. Right. I remember that. Yeah. Because it was like,
you literally have no, no, nothing to give you an anchor to plant yourself. Everything is all
personal preference. And so I think starting from the beginning of, we really should be,
well, we should start with God and is there a God, has he spoken, like you've said before, but then
really, I don't know the balance, sorry, the integration of self-doubt. Like you need to,
you need to train kids on, yes, you have value, you're made in God's image, but you,
you should not trust yourself at all. Like we're really our sinners. And I know that sounds really
harsh in today's world about like telling little kids of their sinners, but I'm just,
my problem is I trust myself too much. And I keep thinking that I can figure it out. And
the older I get, the more I'm like, oh my goodness, I'm just so desperately need
God's wisdom. Cause I, I don't know. So maybe that's more of a starting place with kids is
reminding them that they're not the source of truth or shouldn't trust themselves. I don't know.
I don't know what, what is going to teach that versus saying it. I wonder how much we,
if there's even a problem with, have you read, you guys read, flash child in the woods.
I only heard you heard me talk about it. Oh, just sucks. Okay. Yeah. So tell me about it.
It's a fascinating, the guy wrote a book. Gosh, it's kind of probably 20 years now ago. Yeah.
Called the last child in the woods. And he's done a few since then. And he, but his premise is the
idea of nature deficit disorder. And, and we have no idea what failure to get out into green spaces
costs us the failure to do that. What does it cost us? And, and I honestly think where I learned not
to trust myself and somehow simultaneously a grew in confidence in myself, a healthy confidence
was out in the woods was, was knowing, okay, I can, I can do things. I can accomplish things.
I can handle things and I can make the dumbest decisions and, and knowing that both are true
about the same person, it does not cancel out my sense of confidence or competence or whatever
that I know that I cannot do certain things and I can not capable of it. And I am capable of doing
extremely dumb things. Um, and I feel like I learned so many of those lessons. Some I certainly
learned like from my dad or from working outside or from seeing that kind of stuff play out.
But I feel like a lot of them I learned cause and effect, like I can jump that
and, and being sure that I could, and then getting about halfway across and then being dirty and
muddy for the rest of the day, because, you know, I didn't make it. And so like, I just,
I don't know. I don't know what we're costing. You know, the thought that I can, you know,
build, you build a fort and then it falls over and you're like, what did I do wrong? It's just a,
how do I, uh, anyway, I don't know what all we're losing is, is it that we were on when we're online,
when we're playing video games or whatever, we never, there's all, you can always start over
that you can't, I don't, anyway, but the, what go back to your wilderness thing is it teaches you
none of this stuff out here cares about your feelings. It's just going to happen. There's
laws laws of nature or the weather. Yeah. None of it cares about you and you are helpless
and in a lot of ways and you've got to learn how to fit into this world versus
that is a great role or something. Yeah, it does not. I can, I can impact it. I can change it. It's,
it's very modern in that I am a, an active member of creation, but I am not, I do not dictate
the rules or the laws. Like the world becomes a, a, the material with which I build my home,
but I'm not the one who made the world. And if I do something dumb, it will make me pay.
It won't, it won't rescue me. Yeah. That's a, that is really interesting. That thought.
So yeah, it's just like machinery. It's like working with a table saw. It's just going to do its own
thing. It isn't care about, oh my mistake. Like it doesn't care. You're going to lose a finger.
Like it's, it's just mechanical and it's, has nothing to do with how it makes you feel. It's
just like, there's a law here that you've got to respect and learn to follow. And if you think
about it, that's kind of the weird thing, even with transgender stuff is we're saying,
I don't care what biology tells me. I'm going to do my own thing. I'm going to change it.
And it's like, we think we can, we can do this. And it's like totally going against what nature,
what biology tells us. And it's sad. Surely there aren't consequences to going with how I feel
versus the external realities. Yeah. And, and we've somehow convinced ourselves of that.
And it makes it really difficult because I, and maybe it creates a generational thing. I don't
know. But part of me is like, I just, I can't imagine that making sense to me. Like I'm trying
to imagine being out there in the woods or operating a chainsaw or, or whatever and going,
no, no, this tree's going to fall where I want it to fall. Like it's unless I invest a whole lot
of time and energy. And even then it's still going to fall where it falls. And if I don't play
according to its rules, it's going to fall wherever it falls. And I don't have, I mean, I can,
if I follow the rules, I can maybe make it fall where I want it to. And that's a cool thing to be
able to do, to be able to make a tree fall where you want it to. But as my kids got to see, just a
few weeks ago, maybe a couple months ago now, like I, I set up a giant, I mean, probably a hundred
foot pine tree and it was going to fall perfectly down the hill and everything was right. And just
as I cut one of the wedges out, a trab, a gust of wind hit it and blew it uphill into my wedge up
into my uphill cut and like, well, it's not going downhill now. Like it's not, there's nothing,
there's no force that I can create that that one gust of wind. And so unless I get a gust of wind
the other direction, and that wasn't happening, I now get to fall at sideways. And I'm like,
I now get to fall at sideways, but at least it won't follow my house. But, and so, but it was like,
there was nothing, it did not care how I felt about where it fell. That's really intriguing
that the natural world, I have a friend who's a doctor right now and, and she's in doing,
she's doing some of the stuff in the, at the mental health level and the, and the, you know,
LGBTQ issues and stuff that is at the medical societies in Texas. And she posted some research
in one of these forums, you know, she's a member, she's supposed to do this. It's for everybody. She
posted, all she did was post some research there and they barred her and said, you know, you create
an unsafe space. This is a medical doctor posting research on a medical site. And the answer was
you're creating an unsafe space. Because it wasn't affirming. Because it wasn't, it wasn't purely
affirming. All it did was call into question. Some of the research was like some of this research is
calling into question some of our assumptions. And, and that was it. And that was it. And at that point,
she's done because like, what world do we live in where, you know, my feelings,
how I feel is much more important than hardline medical research. Yeah.
Yeah. Much less that kind of stuff. So that's a great, you know, my, my prayer is with a lot
of this is that is that there is something that finally people can recognize. It's not that
feelings don't matter. And that's not what any of us are saying, but that there's a, there are truths
that transcend how we feel. Yeah. And that's, we need that and we, and we need those truths because,
and this is key. And this is what I wanted to have this conversation. All of us sometimes feel
things that aren't true or we feel things that aren't based on the truth. I can feel like my
wife doesn't love me, even though all the evidence is that she does just because I'm delusional.
I mean, I can feel things that aren't real, that aren't based in reality. I can feel anxious when
there is nothing that I need to be anxious about. So there's so many examples of this and how
dangerous it is when we don't have anything, anything that, that we can anchor that keep our
emotions from becoming these huge out of control storms and out of control sales. I mean, it's like
we raise our sales in the storm rather than lower our sales and put down anchors, which is what we
need to be doing anyway. Totally. Just some thoughts. Hopefully that's encouraging me for,
some type of encouragement for some people out there who are wrestling through this.
And I think it's also a good reminder, like wherever you are in your faith, if you have not
taken time to maybe address some of these anchors, it is going to be worth it. Whatever time that you
spend to think about the Lord's faithfulness in your life, like you're saying, shared,
say, you know, maybe it is for you and your family to have, you know, little figurines or trinkets or
something that is tangible for you to remember. And when, when your faith is called into question,
is the Lord faithful? Is He here to remind you, dive into scripture, remember those things.
Yeah. I don't think that time will be wasted.
Yeah. I agree. And I think, excuse me, at the heart of it, and it's interesting that we're now
in the middle of a month that's dedicated to the topic of pride, but to think about what,
what you're talking about, Chris, even going out in nature is it's very humbling to realize I'm
really not in control or I don't have much say in this. And I think at the heart of what so many
people struggle is today, it's, but I don't like that. And I don't want to blame it all on, we gave
everybody trophies when they're right. But it's like, I played somehow into it though, but it's
this attitude of you are not the wisest person in the room. It is not all about what you think or
want. And I just can't get away from thinking about like an Isaiah 29, where it says you turn
things upside down, show the potter be regarded as the clay. In other words, you're looking at God,
the potter and saying you're actually, we're reversing the roles that the thing made should
save its maker. He did not make me or the thing formed of him who formed it. He has no understanding.
So either the atheistic route of there is no God, he did not make me. Or even if there is a God,
he doesn't understand. He doesn't get under sexuality and gender. Like either way, it's,
I'm putting myself as the highest authority and it's pride. And that's the biggest thing. And
that's where Jesus just said, yeah, you got to deny yourself, not affirm yourself. It's not all
about what you think, you know. Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed
Faith. If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help
other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an
email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist
Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
